awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Optimal Design of Flaw-tolerant Structures and Material Microarchitectures via Stochastic Topology Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
Topology optimization is a computational process for designing structures and materials that meet some optimality criteria, e.g. minimum weight or maximum stiffness. The technique has gained significant traction among design engineers and has been shown to identify designs where efficient use of materials resulted in unprecedented performance. The objective of this research is to develop a new topology optimization framework capable of designing structural topologies that are robust in the presence of geometric uncertainties. Accounting for dimensional uncertainties in the optimization process is of paramount importance in many engineering applications, for example in processes involving extreme miniaturization of the material architecture, where the physical realization of the optimal design is generally subjected to significant tolerances. The application of this research to state-of-the-art commercially available manufacturing technologies, including additive manufacturing, will greatly impact the development of architected cellular materials and promote technology transfer. Results of this research will be incorporated into graduate courses within the Engineering and Applied Science PhD program at the University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth. This project will provide training for graduate and undergraduate students at UMass Dartmouth (where many students are first generation college students), the University of California, Irvine and Johns Hopkins University.

This research will result in a new design optimization framework capable of designing structural topologies that are robust in the presence of geometric uncertainties. A number of strategies will be explored based on novel integration of stochastic analysis and uncertainty representation and propagation methods with efficient topology optimization techniques and inverse homogenization-based material design frameworks. Stochastic topology optimization frameworks for both continuum and discrete structures will be developed where flaw-tolerance is achieved through careful incorporation of nodal and boundary uncertainties. Novel methodologies for the characterization and representation of geometric uncertainties are planned, including an experimental effort aimed at carefully measuring typical geometric flaws in architected cellular materials fabricated with state-of-the-art additive manufacturing techniques, and quantifying their impact on the statistical variations of the macroscopic mechanical properties. This experimental investigation will feed into the development of a topology optimization framework centered on flaw-tolerance.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Today, design optimization is increasingly prevalent in all engineering disciplines, from aerospace and automobile industries, to civil structures, bioengineering and electronic packaging. Among different design optimization paradigms, topology optimization, which is a computational freeform design framework, has the potential to revolutionize the design process by enabling discovery of novel, high performance materials and structures. The technique has gained significant attention in recent years due to its ability to extend the design evolution to incorporate shape, size, and topological changes simultaneously and the availability of advanced additive manufacturing and 3D printing technologies. This has already resulted in ultra-efficient material distribution layouts with applications at a wide range of scales from the macroscale (e.g. airplane wings), to the micro and nanoscale (e.g. photonic waveguides).

While the power of topology optimization has been fully demonstrated, various sources of variability and flaw, which are almost always uncertain in nature, either in the design variables or in the parameters that define the system are often disregarded. This may lead to designs that are suboptimal or even poorly performing under real-world conditions.

 The efforts in this project led to the development of novel methodologies for robust optimal design of structures and material microarchitectures that allow for the formal embedding of stochastic variabilities in the topological design process. This is of crucial importance particularly in cases where design under severe weight constraints (e.g. lightweight structures or ultra-light materials) or design at micro and nano scales results in architectures that are sensitive to stochastic imperfections. To address a major challenge  in bringing light weighting to its limits, that is the emergence of ultra-slender and thin members, topology optimization strategies were devised that automatically adapt the sizing and topology of structural features in the optimal design to the stability needs of slender elements and result in topologies with superb performance from the perspective of structural stability. In response to another challenge which arises when the incorporation of robustness measures in the design process leads to complex topological features, novel strategies were utilized that allow for “direct and effective” length-scale and complexity control in the topological design process. The main goal here was to be able to efficiently morph a complex ground structure to a “constructible” optimal topology. This is of crucial importance, particularly for applications in civil infrastructure, considering that topology optimization with its wide design space may lead to designs that possess excessively thin or thick features or complex connectivities that render them impractical from the point of view of manufacturability. Effort was also made to devise strategies that allow for the incorporation of topology or manufacturing process dependent uncertainties.

The inclusion of robustness and manufacturability measures, topology dependent uncertainties, and stability constraints is expected to lead to (i) improved optimal design of lightweight materials where severe weight constraint results in ultra-slender elements and complex topological features (ii) improved optimal design of additively manufactured structures where processing induced variabilities are often topology dependent.

The capability to utilize materials optimally, while taking into account the uncertainties that naturally arise as a result of different manufacturing processes has potential impacts in a wide range of applications, from structural engineering to material design, and aerospace and automobile industry. The methods developed in the course of this project are expected to help reduce material usage and mass, leading to material cost savings as well as reductions in operating costs (such as fuel usage).

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/20/2022
Modified by: Mazdak Tootkaboni
